learning_outcomes.description: Clearly define the scope and limitations of a policy research topic in conjunction with leaders in a partner organisation.
Design, develop and implement an in-depth analysis of an identified workplace issue or problem.
Co-develop policy improvements where relevant in conjunction with supervisors.
Produce a comprehensive and professional report addressing the issue or problem.
Engage in a professional, ethical and productive manner with team colleagues in the partner organisation.
Demonstrate professional behaviour appropriate to an early career professional.
Identify and articulate skills and knowledge developed through workplace professional experience.

assessments.assessment_title: Agreement Form (downloadable form to be signed by student and external supervisor)
assessments.task_description:
Students must complete a two page 'project outline' (to be submitted via Turnitin), which clearly states:

1. Agreed research question - make sure you have a well-defined question, and ensure your supervisor and you are in agreement about what it is you will research.

2. Agreed method(s) - Agree with your supervisor which qualitative or quantitative method(s) you will be using to examine the above research question. This should be short but substantive. For example, 'desktop research' is an insufficient description. You should be more illuminating, e.g. 'Comparative case studies of legislation in Queensland, New South Wales, and Victoria. The key focus of comparison will be: aims and effectiveness, with effectiveness judged by a systematic review of the relevant literature.' 

PLEASE NOTE - The Project Outline & Internship Agreement (POIA) Form can be downloaded from the course's Blackboard site (see 'learning resources'), and should be completed and uploaded through Turnitin before the due date.

Assessment tasks are intended to evaluate a student’s abilities, skills, and knowledge. Unless explicitly stated otherwise in the assessment instructions, assessments are to be completed without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT). Failure to comply with this direction may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments for this course will be submitted electronically via Blackboard and using Turnitin.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This assignment requires you to describe any relevant aspects of the organization's history, its aims, its organizational structure, its working procedures (how it manages its main activities), and the wider context within the organization is seeking to fulfil its mission.

QPRI interns can use their Parliamentary Proceedings paper for this submission, and follow the QPRI guidelines rather than the above writing guidelines. All other interns are expected to adhere to the above guidelines when writing their Organization & Institutional Context paper.

Submission: This assignment must be submitted to the School of Political Science and International Studies using Turnitin (for marking purposes).

Plagiarism Warning: Please ensure your assignment meets the UQ Academic Integrity standards (see POLSIS Essay Guide and/or UQ's website on Academic Integrity). Assignments containing one or more sections paraphrased or copied verbatim from other sources without adequate referencing will be reported to the POLSIS Integrity Officer, who will subsequently subject the assignment to closer inspection and reach a decision as to whether penalties for academic misconduct should be applied.

Failure to comply with this direction may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Interns are expected to present a 'short and snappy' 5-minute overview of their internship research/report and then answer 2 questions. 

Interns are expected to prepare and use a PowerPoint (maximum 5 slides), and to address the following five points;

1 - The aim(s) of the research

2 - The method(s) being deployed

3 - The main finding(s)

4 - Implications and/or policy-related recommendations

5 - Suggestions for future research

Assessment tasks are intended to evaluate a student’s abilities, skills, and knowledge. Unless explicitly stated otherwise in the assessment instructions, assessments are to be completed without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT). Failure to comply with this direction may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Please submit your slide presentation via email to charene.hare@uq.edu.au by the due date/time.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Interns are to write a report of between 3500 and 4000 words, depending on the negotiated topic. The internship report should clearly articulate (1) the broad topic of significance being investigated, (2) the specific central question, (3) the methods used to examine this question, (4) the main research findings, and (5) the implications of these findings for current policy practices and/or stakeholder engagement.

A very good report will typically address these five aspects, so you may want to consider structuring your research report in this way.

The completed report must be submitted (a) to the School of Political Science and International Studies using Turnitin (for marking purposes), with a copy provided to the internship organisation in a format preferred by that organisation.

Plagiarism Warning: Please ensure your assignment meets the UQ Academic Integrity standards (see POLSIS Essay Guide and/or UQ's website on Academic Integrity). Assignments containing one or more sections paraphrased or copied verbatim from other sources without adequate referencing will be reported to the POLSIS Integrity Officer, who will subsequently subject the assignment to closer inspection and reach a decision as to whether penalties for academic misconduct should be applied.

Artificial Intelligence Warning: Assessment tasks are intended to evaluate a student’s abilities, skills, and knowledge. Unless explicitly stated otherwise in the assessment instructions, assessments are to be completed without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT). Failure to comply with this direction may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

- Familiarize yourself with the organization's overall aim(s)

- Gain a solid understanding of the aim(s) of your project

- Ensure you are in agreement with your supervisor


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L05, L06

learning_activities.topic:
Reaching agreement about the research project

- Articulate the research question your research will examine

- Consider potential research methods (in addition to Literature Reviewing)

- Ensure you are in agreement with your supervisor

- Apply for Ethical Clearance if research involves human participants


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Reaching agreement about the research project - Articulate the research question your research will examine - Consider potential research methods (in addition to Literature Reviewing) - Ensure you are in agreement with your supervisor - Apply for Ethical Clearance if research involves human participants

learning_activities.topic:
Seminar 2

RESEARCH SCOPING SEMINAR


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

Reviewing relevant social science literature

- Review the existing literature examining your research topic

- Identify relevant existing knowledge and possible knowledge gaps

- Decide whether literature reviewing will suffice to meet organization's needs


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Reviewing relevant social science literature - Review the existing literature examining your research topic - Identify relevant existing knowledge and possible knowledge gaps - Decide whether literature reviewing will suffice to meet organization's needs
